entry.title: Re: Unable to see list data when I run the app
entry.content:
Hello Chuma,

this is the output I get when using list method - 
{ "totalSize": 2, "done": true, "records": [ { "attributes": { "type": "Account", "url": "/services/data/v60.0/sobjects/Account/001gK000005Y8NHQA0" }, "Name": "RapidFlow Logistics", "Delivery_Status__c": "In Transit", "Warehouse_Location__c": "Delhi Northern Warehouse" }, { "attributes": { "type": "Account", "url": "/services/data/v60.0/sobjects/Account/001gK00000AtMjiQAF" }, "Name": "Travel Cargo Logistics", "Delivery_Status__c": "Delivered", "Warehouse_Location__c": "Ahmedabad Distribution Center" } ] }

If I only use data.Salesforce_OAuth1
this is what I get in alert a structure like this-

entry.title: Re: Date Time as a Custom Filter Field
entry.content:
Hi Gagan,

as far as I have understood your problem, there is a difference of timezones of timestamps being sent by a odata request.

What does your backend interpret, or in what timezone is shown when using timestamps coming from your frontend?

You could convert timestamp on frontend side to UTC, makes sense if your backend expects it.
On backend side, you also could convert imcoming timestamps to UTC also if needed.

Yours,
Thomas

entry.title: Re: Custom Fiori app displays placeholder instead of actu...
entry.content:
@walkerist79 

SmartTable basically shows table columns based on UI annotations. You only need to specify the entitySet like the example below:

			<smartTable:SmartTable id="LineItemsSmartTable" entitySet="LineItemsSet" smartFilterId="smartFilterBar" tableType="Table" enableExport="true" beforeExport="onBeforeExport" useVariantManagement="true" useTablePersonalisation="true" header="Line Items" showRowCount="true" persistencyKey="SmartTableAnalytical_Explored" enableAutoBinding="true" class="sapUiResponsiveContentPadding" enableAutoColumnWidth="true" editTogglable="true" app:useSmartToggle="true">
				<!-- layout data used to make the table growing but the filter bar fixed -->
				<smartTable:layoutData>
					<FlexItemData growFactor="1" baseSize="0%"/>
				</smartTable:layoutData>
			</smartTable:SmartTable>

entry.title: DB2 11.5 LUW - HADR rebuild from online backup ?
entry.content:
Hello,

I am currently upgrading an IBM AIX OS based DB2 system. It was DB2 V9.7 at the start and therfore requires the HADR configuration to be rebuilt based on the IBM DB2 upgrade documentation on the process. 

The SAP ERP EHP5 database is 10TB in size , therefore a significant amount of time would be required to take an offline backup to the shared storage and then use that backup to rebuild the HACMP secondary database.

I've been searching the last few days on the possibility of using an online backup of the production primary database to avoid extended downtime, but almost all the hits I've found indicate offline backup is used. I found very few with online, but these posts looked like a small test type database was used for the example. 

Has anyone got any pointers on the best way to build a heavily used productive ERP DB2 HADR primary to the secondary with an online backup - or will the offline be the way - keeping the primary production SAP system down untill the HADR starts are done after the restore completes on the secondary HADR host.

Regards,

Brian.

entry.title: Re: Date Time as a Custom Filter Field
entry.content:
Hi Thomas,

Let me give you an example of my problem.

Let’s say I have a filter field on the List Report page of my application named "Start Date Time", which accepts date-time input from the user. Now, when I select a date like 2025-08-07 00:00:00, the actual value sent in the OData request is:

 

$filter=startDateTime eq 2025-08-06T18:30:00.000Z

This happens because I'm in the IST timezone (UTC+5:30), and the browser automatically adjusts the time to UTC when sending the request.

However, my backend service expects the value to be in UTC without any timezone offset manipulation — it expects exactly 2025-08-07T00:00:00Z.

So this mismatch leads to incorrect filtering of records because the time shifted by 5.5 hours causes the backend to fetch results for the previous day.

What I want:

I’d like to override the behavior of the filter bar such that when the user selects a date and time, it is converted to UTC manually and sent exactly in the expected format — like 2025-08-07T00:00:00Z.
You can connect me in Teams (gagan.prajapati@sap.com)
Thanks,
Gagan

entry.title: SAP 分析云建模扩展与集成 2025 QRC3 版本新功能速览
entry.content:
目的   

尊敬的 SAP 社区同事：   

在 2025 年 QRC3 版本（BDC中的 SAC建模模块）中，我们为您带来了一系列重磅更新，功能焕然一新！

温馨提示：QRC3 版本将于八月中旬在您的客户端正式上线，以下内容为您抢先揭秘新功能亮点，敬请期待！ 

功能总览   

本次更新为您带来三大核心能力，详情如下：   

  1. 全新公式：WAVG（加权平均值）   
  2. FIRST、LAST 与 AVERAGE 支持含无值数据的异常聚合 
  3. 数据导出 API —— 增量聚合（Delta Aggregation） 

1.全新公式：WAVG（加权平均值）   

WAVG（加权平均）公式现已上线建模器。该公式可根据指定权重成员的对应值，计算某一成员的加权平均值，适用于标准模型和账户模型。 

加权平均计算方式： 

Dimension  

Price 

Stock 

Price * Stock 

Bread 

2 

10 

20 

Bread 

3 

20 

60 

Bread 

4 

30 

120 

Total 

8 

60 

200 

表 1：含产品、价格与库存数据的示例表   

表 1 列出若干产品及其单价与库存量。 

要计算平均价格，请使用以下公式计算： 

(2 + 3 + 4) / 3 = 3 

要计算加权平均价格，请使用以下公式计算： 

(2*10) + (3*20) + (4*30) / (10 + 20 + 30) = 200 / 60 = 3.33 

通过引入权重，加权平均计算能更精准地反映实际价值。 

语法：   

WAVG([度量值] 或 [账户成员], [指定权重], [维度1], [维度2], ..., [维度10]) 

示例：   

图 1：WAVG 语法示例   

上述 WAVG 公式以 [Volume] 作为权重，计算在给定 [Date] 和 [Product] 维度下的 [Price] 加权平均值。   

WAVG 公式最多可引用 10 个维度。   

注意：目前仅支持在层次结构的叶节点（最低层级）对该计算度量进行输入。后续版本计划扩展至其他层级的成员。 

2.FIRST、LAST 与 AVERAGE 支持含无值数据的异常聚合 

新增三种异常聚合方式，现可在单一维度下，对基础度量或基础账户进行 FIRST、LAST 以及 AVERAGE 计算，并包含无值数据： 

  • Average incl. Unbooked计算所选期间内所有聚合值（含无值数据）的平均值。   
  • First incl. Unbooked返回所选期间内最早（时间最靠前）的值，包含无值数据。   
  • Last incl. Unbooked  返回所选期间内最新（时间最靠后）的值，包含无值数据。 

图 2：建模器中新增的异常聚合选项 

这些异常聚合方式同时支持标准模型与账户模型，可在聚合数据时给出更精确的结果。 

【示例】“Average including unbooked” 异常聚合： 

图 3：示例说明“Average incl. Unbooked”如何将期间内的所有月份纳入计算，而非仅含有值数据的月份   

在上例中，对某一基础度量应用了“Average incl. Unbooked”异常聚合。各季度合计：Q1 为 100，Q2 为 200，Q3 为 300，Q4 为 400。   

仅考虑有值数据时，平均值是这些值的总和，除以有值条目的数量，即 

(100 + 200 + 300 + 400) ÷ 4 = 250   

考虑含无值数据时，期间共 12 个月全部纳入计算，得到更精确的平均异常聚合，即   

  (100 + 200 + 300 + 400) ÷ 12 ≈ 83.33 

【示例】“First incl. Unbooked” 异常聚合： 

图 4：示例展示“First incl. Unbooked”如何将期间所有月份纳入计算，而非仅含有值数据的月份   

图 4 通过对比说明：使用“First incl. Unbooked”异常聚合时，系统会考虑首月无值数据值；而传统“First”聚合仅返回有值数据的首个值。   

即使二月已有数据，顶层仍显示无值数据值，因为公式已将一月（无数据）纳入计算，从而为该期间内的“First”异常聚合提供更精确的结果。 

图 5：示例说明“Last incl. Unbooked”如何在给定期间内把无值数据纳入“最后值”计算   

图5展示了“Last incl. Unbooked”与“Last（仅含有值数据）”两种聚合方式的差异。在传统“Last”模式下，10 月已有有值数据 400，且它是最后一个含有值数据的期间，因此 400 被带到层级顶层并显示出来。而“Last incl. Unbooked”同样把 10 月的 400 纳入计算，但最后一个期间是 12 月，该月存在无值数据。由于该无值数据也被视为有效，12 月的数据被推送至顶层，从而得到更贴近真实情况的 Last 聚合结果。 

3.数据导出 API —— 增量聚合（Delta Aggregation） 

数据导出 API 现已扩展，新增 “FactDataAggregation” 端点，支持将已聚合的事实数据增量导出。   

这意味着，系统可先把发生变动的事实数据聚合，再仅导出这些聚合结果，而无需导出所有变动明细。该功能与 S/4 使用聚合事实数据的方式相辅相成。   

建模者也可在模型的 “API Subscriptions” 标签页内直接访问此功能。 

图 6：在模型的“创建订阅”区域中显示的“事实数据增量聚合”实体集   

增量聚合示例： 

Account 

Product 

Sales 

Account1 

Water 

100 

Account1 

Juice 

150 

Account2 

Water 

200 

Account2 

Juice 

150 

表2：Account1与Account2包含产品及销售额。 

表2显示，Account1和Account2共包含2种产品，每种产品在不同期间的销售金额各异。 

Account

表3：Account1 和 Account2的聚合值   

接下来，我们对两个账户的销售额进行调整： 

Account 

Product

Account1

表4：销售额已发生变动，体现为事实数据更新 

Account1中“Water”的销售额由 100 调整为 110   

Account1中“Juice”的销售额由 150 调整为 80   

Account2中“Water”的销售额由 200 调整为 75   

Account2中“Juice”的销售额保持不变   

由此重新计算得到的聚合事实数据如下： 

Account 

Sales 

Account1 

((110 - 100) + (80 - 150)) = -60 

Account2 

((75-200) + (150 – 150)) = -125 

表5：聚合值的计算方式 

这些值即为通过“FactDataAggregation”端点，或在模型的 “API Subscriptions”中使用“Fact Data Delta Aggregation”实体集后，将要导出的聚合结果。 

结论   

总之，作为 2025 年 QRC3 版本的一部分，SAC（Business Data Cloud 模块）在“建模扩展”与“集成”领域推出了以下新功能与更新： 

    1.新增 WAVG 公式：可按对应权重成员的值，计算某成员的加权平均。   

    2.三种新的异常聚合方式   

  • First incl. Unbooked：在选定期间内，返回最早值（含无值数据）。   
  • Last incl. Unbooked：在选定期间内，返回最新值（含无值数据）。   
  • Average incl. Unbooked：在选定期间内，返回所有聚合值的平均（含无值数据）。 

    3.数据导出API 扩展：新增 “FactDataAggregation” 端点，支持将事实数据的“聚合增量”导出；建模者也可在模型的 API Subscriptions 标签页中，使用全新的 “Fact Data Delta Aggregation” 实体集。 

 

如有任何疑问，欢迎在下方留言，或前往SAC问答论坛发帖提问。

想进一步了解 FastTrack 与季度发布周期（QRC）的详情，请查阅相关 SAP 知识库文章。

更多产品资讯、最佳实践与社区资源，请访问SAC社区页面。

如需查看 2025 年 QRC 各租户的具体更新日期，可参考《SAP Analytics Cloud 季度发布周期（QRC）2025 租户更新时间表》。

想提前了解即将推出的新功能，欢迎浏览 SAP Road Map Explorer。

感谢阅读！

entry.title: Re: SD: Rounding differences in invoicing
entry.content:
Even though 35 000 × 9 % = 3 150.00 exactly, SAP SD can still show 3 149.98 on each item when creating the invoice. This is by design, not a system bug, and is caused by how SAP rounds “group” vs. “item” conditions and distributes header-level values to line items.

What is happening in your cause is that

  • You’ve got a surcharge condition type (say, ZA09) that’s marked as both an item and group condition in V/06.
  • At item processing, SAP calculates the surcharge per line: – 35 000.00 × 9 % = 3 150.00 ➔ rounded to 2 decimals = 3 150.00
  • Because it’s a group condition, SAP then: – Adds up all line net values (6 × 35 000 = 210 000), calculates 210 000 × 9 % = 18 900.00 – Distributes that 18 900.00 back to the 6 lines – During distribution the system must split and round each share (18 900.00 ÷ 6 = 3 150.00, but distribution logic yields 3 149.98 on most lines and 3 150.12 on one line)
  • The first time you look at the item lines, you see the pure item-level 3 150.00. But once you enter the header conditions, SAP re-runs the group calculation & distribution, so your items jump to the “distributed” values (3 149.98) and the tiny rounding variance shows up.

If you don’t need header-level distribution, simply uncheck Group Condition on your surcharge in V/06. Now every line is calculated and rounded in isolation—no distribution, no variance.

SAP Note 80183 describes ways to minimize rounding variances by using formula routines 919/920 on all pre-net discount/surcharge conditions, ensuring SAP rounds at the point you choose (item vs. header) Follow the note’s “Variant 2” or “Variant 3” recommendations if you have complex multi-condition pricing.

All Admin endpoints are routed through us1 data center, which has always been the main data center for these services. Hope this is helpful.

Regards,
Anand Raj

entry.title: Navigation Issue in CAP UI5 Apps on BTP CF Fiori Launchpad After Page Refresh
entry.content:
Hi all,

We are building several CAP-based UI5 applications deployed on BTP Cloud Foundry.

When these applications run inside the Fiori Launchpad (FLP), we encounter a navigation issue: if a user refreshes the page explicitly, they are unable to navigate back using either the browser’s back button or the Launchpad’s NavBack button (next to the SAP home icon). Initially, the user remains stuck on the current page (the browser hash doesn’t change either). After a few clicks, they are suddenly redirected straight to the FLP home page.

There are no errors/warnings/info in the browser's console log.

This issue does not occur when the same UI5 apps are run in standalone mode (accessed via the HTML5 Applications tab in the BTP Cockpit), nor does it affect Fiori Elements apps running in FLP.

Here’s how we handle navigation and routing in our UI5 app view controllers (TypeScript):

Navigating Forward

// params are routing parameters such as mandatory parameter
public navToView(viewName: string, params?: object): void {
    this.getRouter().navTo(viewName, params ? params : {});
}

Example usage:

public onNavToNextView(): void {
    this.navToView("nextView");
}

We even added a nav back button, but it has the same problem as well.

Navigating Back

// same, params is just an obj for routing parameters
public navBackToView(viewName: string, params?: object): void {
    const history = History.getInstance();
    const previousHash = history.getPreviousHash();

    if (previousHash !== undefined) {
        window.history.go(-1);
    } else {
        this.getRouter().navTo(viewName, params ? params : {}, true);
    }
}

Example usage:

// press event for nav back button
public onNavBack(): void {
    this.navBackToView("previousView");
}

This is how we initialise the router in the Component.ts file:

this.getRouter().initialize();

This is the routing configuration in the manifest.json file:

"routing": {
      "config": {
        "routerClass": "sap.m.routing.Router",
        "controlAggregation": "pages",
        "controlId": "app",
        "transition": "slide",
        "type": "View",
        "viewType": "XML",
        "path": "myapp.view",
        "async": true,
        "bypassed": {
          "target": "notFound"
        }
      },
      "routes": [
        {
          "name": "RouteHome",
          "pattern": ":?query:",
          "target": ["TargetHome"]
        },
        {
          "pattern": "login",
          "name": "login",
          "target": "login"
        }
      ],
      "targets": {
        "TargetHome": {
          "id": "Home",
          "name": "Home",
          "level": 1
        },
        "login": {
          "viewName": "Login",
          "viewId": "login",
          "level": 1
        },
        "notFound": {
          "id": "notFound",
          "name": "NotFound",
          "transition": "show"
        }
      }
    }

 

Are we missing something in our implementation? We’ve followed UI5 examples from the Demo Kit. Could this be a known or unknown issue/bug with FLP itself?

Any insights or suggestions would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: EF5008 No special G/L acct defined for acct type D sp...
entry.content:
When you post a down-payment via F-29, SAP uses your customizing in FBKP/OBXR to look up the correct vendor‐reconciliation (down-payment) G/L account automatically. However, with BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST, the BAPI doesn’t always call the same “pick‐up” logic—unless you explicitly provide either:

  • The special G/L reconciliation account in your BAPI‐input tables, or
  • The correct customizing entries that the BAPI actually reads.

If neither is found, you get the error - No special G/L acct defined for acct type D sp.G/L ind. A recon.acct (Message F5 008)

In FBKP, set up Offsetting entries in Special G/L transactions for Account Type = D (Vendor), Special G/L Indicator = A (Down Payment) and enter your vendor‐reconcil. account here.

The other alternate is Alternate reconciliation via OBXR. In OBXR, ensure your Special G/L indicator A is mapped to the correct reconciliation account for each vendor‐account group or company code. This is the fallback the standard GUI uses—BAPI only reads OBXR if you leave the recon‐account blank in your input. If either FBKP or OBXR customizing is missing or incomplete, F-29 will still work (it can pull from the vendor master), but the BAPI will choke.

So in summary, to fix your issue,
ensure FBKP/OBXR Customizing where you have to define the down‐payment reconcil. G/L account for Account Type D & Indicator A.
populate or override via BAPI where you need to include RECON_ACCOUNT in your ACCOUNTRECEIVABLE/PAYABLE table and mark it in the X‐structure.

entry.title: Re: Transport the service Catalogue Issue
entry.content: It seems you're having trouble creating a transport for the C_GLACCOUNTHIERARCHYNODE_SRV service in transaction /n/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE, even after accepting the standard warning message. The most likely cause is a missing authorization or an issue with your system's transport configuration (STMS). You should ask your Basis team to verify that your user has the necessary permissions to create transport requests and that your system has a valid transport route configured. This will likely resolve the issue by enabling the pop-up where you can assign the service to a transport.

entry.title: Re: Unify ECC and NetWeaver HCM during the S/4HANA conver...
entry.content:
Hello Anderson,

 

If you want to unify two systems into one, the recommended approach is selective data transition. You can choose to do this either all at once or step by step. For example, you could first convert your ECC system to SAP S/4HANA, and then selectively move your HCM system into the new SAP S/4HANA.

To learn more about this transition path, please review this information: https://support.sap.com/en/offerings-programs/support-services/data-management-landscape-transformation/selective-data-transition-engagement.html

 

Regards,

Jose M.

entry.title: ​Advanced Developing Skills to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management
entry.content:
Chapter 1: Define the Purpose 

This guide helps Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition partners and customers to build custom mobile applications by integrating the Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API (from SAP Business Accelerator Hub) with SAP Build Code. 

Previously, we published a step-by-step guide blog detailing the development process for a sample mobile application.
（A Step-by-Step Guide to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management Using SAP Build Code：https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-sap/a-step-by-step-guide-to-build-a-custom-mobile-apps-for-warehouse-management/ba-p/14155800）

This follow-up article will highlight key features and advantages of the SAP Build Code-Mobile Develop Kit that enhance development, including: 

  • Use the built-in "Actions" to quickly generate a REST request. 
  • Debugging methods for mobile applications. 
  • Joule AI co-development, with examples of automated code assistance to accelerate the development process. 

 

Chapter 2: Use Actions with JavaScript 

This chapter introduces key points for using Actions to create and send a REST request. Actions are a set of built-in instructions in SAP Build Code. They enable you to control mobile application behaviors such as navigation, messaging, document opening, and other behaviors using visual no-code or low-code methods. Additionally, they support generating instructions for sending requests via REST services. For a detailed tutorial, you can refer to this guide. 

SendRequest - Mobile Development Kit References 
Step to create a REST Action: 

1.Right-click the Actions folder in the file directory of the project and select "MDK: New Action". 

 2. Choose "REST Service Send Request" and click "Next". 

 3. You can configure your service URL and additional properties here. "Success Action" and "Failure Action" refer to the actions to be taken after the request succeeds or fails, respectively. 

 4. The obtained result can be retrieved via actionBinding, and further operations can be performed on it. 
Using example in previous Blog: （A Step-by-Step Guide to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management Using SAP Build Code：https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-sap/a-step-by-step-guide-to-build-a-custom-mobile-apps-for-warehouse-management/ba-p/14155800）

Set the "Target" of the action to the rest request for getting warehousetask： 

{{TestServerURL}}/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001 

Then the returned warehousetask information will be as shown in the figure below.  

 

Next, we can create a Rule use the following example code. 

Example code: 

export default function ShowWarehouseTask(clientAPI) { 

  alert(JSON.stringify(clientAPI.getActionBinding())); 

}

Last step, bind the "Success Action" of the send request action to this rule file. This means that if the request returns a success, this successful rule will be triggered. We can then bind this action to the button on the page and click it to trigger it (for specific methods, refer to the previous blog).

 

 

Chapter 3: Tracing API Request in Mobile App 

For tracing request and returned information sent in mobile app. 

1. Open the mobile service on the storyboard, which can be found in Quick Access. 

 2. Scroll down to the bottom of the "Add on Features" section. If the "Network Trace" option is not visible, click the nearby "Add Feature" button to enable it. 

 3. After clicking ​​"Start Recording"​​, use the mobile app to send requests. The log will capture all network requests. After downloading the ​​recording​​, view the request status, response values, and other details ​​to analyze the issue​​. 

 

 

Chapter 4: Joule Example: Using Joule AI to Accelerate Development 

Joule AI integrated into this web-based compiler enhances rapid development. 

However, ​​for complex actions​​, its generated code may lack precision or executability, requiring manual inspection and refinement. ​​For simpler actions and UIs​​, Joule significantly accelerates development—​​the clearer your language descriptions​​, ​​the more tailored content Joule generates​​. 

​​Key commonly used commands include:​ 

1. /mdk-gen-action 
Automatically generates action configurations and embeds them into mobile service files. These actions can be bound to UI elements (e.g., buttons) to trigger workflows—such as navigation, message prompts, or REST API calls (e.g., GET/POST). 

2. /mdk-gen-page 
Generates UI pages based on OData entity metadata or custom requirements. 

You may also use /help to discover other available features.  

 

​Usage Example​​: Taking the use of the Cancel Warehouse Task Request in the WOWT API as an example, we need to use the Joule function to generate action code and UI interfaces. 

Input in Joule： 

"I need a 'send request' action to send a POST request to:   

{{starturl}}/sap/opu/odata4/.../WarehouseTask(   

  EWMWarehouse='{{whse}}',   

  WarehouseTask='{{wt}}',   

  WarehouseTaskItem='{{wt_item}}'   

)/SAP__self.CancelWarehouseTask?sap-client={{client}}   

Headers:   

- If-Match: *   

- X-CSRF-Token: {{csrf_token}}"

 

For UI Creation: 

/mdk-gen-page #your_service  

"Generate a form page with:   

Text input fields for:   

   - Warehouse Task ID   

   - Warehouse Item ID   

   - Warehouse Location   

A confirmation button labeled 'Cancel Task'"

Output: 

Next, you only need to make simple modifications to quickly generate a cancel warehouse task request page. 

 

 

Conclusion   

This guide introduces some advanced usage methods of SAP Build Code as well as distinctive tools that are different from those in other development approaches, etc. The main content includes: 

  • Using built-in tools "Actions" to simplify REST API integration. 
  • Debugging network requests directly in the app. 
  • Leveraging Joule AI to speed up basic code and UI creation. 

It is hoped that these advanced methods can be helpful to you when developing mobile apps for our API in Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

 

Referenced Data and Additional Training Lessons 

Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API 
Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API (from SAP Business Accelerator Hub) 

 

Official tutorial web for mobile development kit clients. 

SAP Tutorial Navigator | Tutorials for SAP Developers 

 

Explore the mobile development kit SDK and build a custom Android/iOS client, enable push notifications, and create extensions. 

Brand Your Customized App with Mobile Development Kit SDK | SAP Tutorials 

 

Customize the look and feel of your MDK app with extension controls using metadata approach or Native script plugins. 

Create Extension Controls in Mobile Development Kit (MDK) Apps | SAP Tutorials 

 

Increase your understanding of the mobile development kit, learn how to create, delete a record, how to display the data from the related entity, and how to upload client logs to mobile services. 

Enhance Your First MDK App with Additional Functionalities | SAP Tutorials 

 

Become proficient with the mobile development kit by learning how to handle an error archive, add styling, deep link, and leverage OData annotations. 

Level Up with the Mobile Development Kit | SAP Tutorials 

 

Use the SAP Mobile Services mobile development kit (MDK) to create your first multi-channel (mobile and web) application, connect to an OData backend, and use MDK controls to enhance it.  

Create Your First MDK Application | SAP Tutorials 

 

Help document for Metadata reference. 
SendRequest - Mobile Development Kit References

entry.title: Unlocking On-Premise Data for SAP Joule Studio with SAP BTP Destinations
entry.content:
1 – Why this matters

Since July 2025, Joule Studio has supported SAP BTP Destination service as a first-class data source. In practice, that means you can point the copilot to any on-premise or partner API that is exposed through a Destination, without replicating data to the cloud. Joule then consumes the data securely at runtime, treats it just like a native Skill, and returns answers in natural language. 
https://architecture.learning.sap.com/docs/ref-arch/06ff6062dc

For the many customers who still run SAP ECC, S/4HANA On-Premise, or tightly-regulated third-party systems, this closes the one remaining gap: Joule’s AI smarts are now reachable before a full RISE-with-SAP migration. You still need a Joule client, from SAP Build WorkZone, for example.

 

2 – How the plumbing works

  1. Set up SAP Cloud Connector

    Create an outbound tunnel from your DMZ to the BTP subaccount and whitelist the internal host and port. No inbound firewall holes are necessary.

  2. Define a Destination

    In BTP, configure a Destination with ProxyType = OnPremise that points to the internal OData, REST or RFC endpoint. Add OAuth2 SAML-Bearer, Basic, or principal propagation as required.

  3. Import in Joule Studio

    In the new “Data Services” tab, choose Import from Destination. Joule Studio inspects the OpenAPI spec or $metadata document and generates an Action (Skill) interface automatically.

Run the chat

At runtime, Joule resolves the Destination, routes the call through Cloud Connector, and grounds the LLM’s answer on live on-prem data. Authorizations remain intact because Joule forwards the user’s JWT or system credentials.

Note: You still need to wrap legacy RFC/BAPI calls in OData V2, CAP or RAP facades so that Destinations can expose them cleanly.

 

3 – Three concrete scenarios for FR & BE customers

Scenario 1 – Luxury retailer in France (ECC6 + BW on HANA)

A store manager types: “Stock du sac ‘Montpellier’ au Printemps Haussmann ?” Joule calls BAPI_MATERIAL_STOCK_REQ_LIST through the Destination and replies in French within seconds, eliminating phone calls and SAP GUI look-ups during peak tourist season.

Scenario 2 – Belgian discrete manufacturer (S/4HANA OP 2021 FPS02)

An engineer asks: “Montre-moi les cinq derniers résultats QC pour le lot 450123.” Joule fetches data from the QA32 OData service, surfaces inspection characteristics and links to the certificate of analysis PDF, cutting lead time on corrective actions required by EU MDR regulations.

Scenario 3 – Cross-border energy utility (FR/BE) with third-party DMS + ECC

A field technician on an ATEX-rated iPad says: “Quelle est la procédure de purge pour la vanne 14-BE-125 ?” Joule simultaneously queries a Documentum REST API for technical drawings and the ECC equipment master via two Destinations, providing hands-free access and reducing pipeline downtime.

 

 

4 – Getting started

  1. Upgrade your Joule Studio tenant to the July 2025 feature bundle (or later).

  2. Patch Cloud Connector 2.17 or newer to enable JWT forwarding.

  3. Model an on-prem API façade (CAP, RAP, SAP Gateway) and expose a $metadata endpoint.

  4. Create design-time and runtime Destinations, setting WebIDEEnabled = true.

  5. Import, test and publish the new Skill inside Joule Studio.

  6. Roll out to pilot users, collect unanswered questions and refine the Skill.

     

5 – Why this is a big deal

  • It bridges the last mile for hybrid landscapes: on-prem data stays on-prem, yet Joule can reach it securely.

  • It eases cloud adoption: start with one high-impact use case, prove value, and migrate workloads at your own pace.

  • It reduces change management: users keep one chat UI while the back-end location is abstracted away.

  • It is future-proof: the same Destination can later point to your RISE system with minimal refactoring.

Yes, some development effort is still required (especially to wrap legacy BAPIs and secure tokens) but the payoff in faster decisions and higher user satisfaction is already evident among early adopters.

Happy building, and let Joule talk to all your data! 🚀

entry.title: Re: Issue with Automatic Inspection plan assignment to in...
entry.content:
When you have multiple inspection plans (group counters) for the same material with the same Usage, SAP’s standard auto‐assignment logic for GR (Usage 04) only looks at

  • the task list group (from the material master),
  • the Usage code, and
  • the material / plant assignments in each plan.

It does not factor in Vendor for Usage 04. So when two plans both have Usage 04 and are assigned to the same material / plant, the system simply picks the lowest group counter (GC 1) every time—even if you restricted one plan to Vendor 2 in QP02.

Below are couple of options:

  1. Manual Selection via CRTD Status. Configure both plans with the same Usage. When MIGO posts GR, the lot will go to CRTD (Created) instead of REL (Released) if multiple valid group counters exist. User must then manually choose GC 1 or GC 2 in QA01/QA02. No coding change needed; only a process tweak.
  2. Differentiate by Usage Code. Give GC 1 Usage 04 (Goods Receipt) and GC 2 a custom Usage (e.g., Z4). Vendor 1 lots pick Usage 04 → GC 1. Vendor 2 lots won’t auto‐assign (no Z4 usage for GR)—they land in CRTD and you pick manually (or build logic to auto‐release). Works without enhancement but complicates Usage management.
  3. Use a Quality Info Record. Create a Q‐Info record (transaction QP13/QP21) for Material + Vendor 2 and assign GC 2 in it. Standard QM logic will check for a vendor-specific info record before falling back to task list‐group logic. Lots from Vendor 2 then pick GC 2 automatically.
  4. Add Custom Logic via User-Exit or BAdI. Implement the BAdI /QM/QPL_PLAN_DETERM (or the classic user-exit in function module QP_SELECT_INSPECTION_PLAN) to inject Vendor into the selection criteria. In your routine, read the purchase order’s vendor (from the inspection‐lot source data) and choose GC 2 when it matches Vendor 2, otherwise GC 1. Fully automated and rules-driven; requires ABAP.

Recommended approaches are

  • If you need truly seamless GR‐time plan assignment by vendor, the Quality Info Record route (Option 3) is the least invasive—no ABAP, no custom Usage codes, and it piggybacks on standard QM master-data precedence logic.
  • If you already have many materials and prefer a code-based rule (for example, you’ll roll out more vendor-specific plans later), go with Option 4 and implement the QM BAdI for inspection plan determination.

Also have a look at SAP Note 487539

entry.title: Re: Condition Types in Purchase Orders and Contracts (Hea...
entry.content:
Hello @Shubham120798 

Thank you for your detailed feedback and for raising these important clarifications regarding condition types in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for Procurement.

Here’s a summary addressing your points:

Purchasing Condition Types in S/4HANA Public Cloud:
You are correct: the standard delivered condition types for Purchasing (MM) are distinct from those used in Sales (SD). In S/4HANA Public Cloud, you will find purchasing-specific condition types such as DL01 (Delivery Costs), DRN1 (Discount), DRQ1 (Quantity Discount), DPR2 (Document/PO Header Discount), FGW1 (Freight), PB00 (Gross Price), and more. These are maintained within the cloud solution and available for use in purchasing documents such as purchase orders and contracts.

Header- vs. Item-Level Condition Types:

  • Condition types like DPR2 are configured for use at the document header level, so they can be entered for the entire PO or contract.
  • Types such as DL01, DRN1, DRQ1, FGW1, and PB00 are item-level, applying to individual purchase order line items.
  • The assignment (header vs. item) is defined in configuration and cannot overlap for a single condition type.

Customization and Hiding of Condition Types:

  • Only those condition types included in the active purchasing calculation schema (pricing procedure) for a particular document type will appear in the UI; all others are effectively hidden from end users.
  • While you cannot "hide" SAP standard condition types globally via SSCUIs, you have full control over which appear by configuring your calculation schema through tools like SSCUI 101095 (Set Calculation Schema – Purchasing).
  • You may also create custom condition types to suit unique requirements.

Pricing Procedure Flexibility:

  • The pricing procedure (calculation schema) in S/4HANA Public Cloud is editable within the available cloud configuration options. This allows you to add or remove standard and custom condition types, or adjust their order and calculation logic, as permitted by SAP’s fit-to-standard cloud principles.

Summary:

  • The system provides a standard set of MM-specific condition types, with clear options for header and item assignment.
  • You control which condition types are active via your calculation schema configuration.
  • Pricing procedures are not fixed in Public Cloud; you can adapt them to your procurement business needs within SAP’s best-practice framework.

Condition Type for Pricing in Purchasing – Read-SAP Help

Pricing and Conditions-SAP help 

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Including @OData.publish:true on v4 OData service.
entry.content:
No.

@odata.publish is an older altenative to create OData services (it only works with OData V2).

It was created even before the existance of RAP, service definitions and bindings and most likely even before OData V4 was officially released. 

In other words, it was never a pre-requisite. Just do not use it if you go with service definition + binding.

You can still use it for whatever reason - the system will not complain about using it + using the same CDS in a service definition but it's definitely not needed and makes things confusing.

entry.title: Re: Dynamic Text box
entry.content:
Hello @Carvalho_A1 

Thank you for your inquiry regarding the setup of fiscal year variants (FYV) for SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

You can indeed create a custom Fiscal Year Variant to accommodate non-standard quarters such as December to February, March to May, and so forth, tailored to your reporting requirements. This is done by copying the standard quarterly variant QT and adjusting the period start and end dates as needed.

How to proceed:

  • Use the app Define Fiscal Year Variants (SSCUI 102447) in your SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant.
  • Copy the standard variant QT and configure your custom quarters (periods).
  • Ensure the variant has the appropriate number of posting periods.
  • Assign this custom fiscal year variant in your DRC report configuration under the “Fiscal Year Variant” field.

For detailed guidance, please refer to the official SAP Help Portal documentation for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud here:
Define Your Own Fiscal Year Variant - SAP Help Portal

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: How can I configure the Supply chain unit, Party entitled to dispose, Custodian to EWM warehouse?
entry.content:
How to find the right path in EWM Public Cloud for assigning Supply chain unit, Party entitled to dispose, Custodian to EWM warehouse number?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How can I configure the Supply chain unit, Party enti...
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

The assignment of SCU, Party Entitled to Dispose, Custodian to warehouse is done in SSCUI – 102657 (Set Warehouse Address).

The Party Entitled to Dispose can be configured directly in the SSCUI 102657 (Set Warehouse Address).

The Supply Chain Unit is created referred to: SCU_<WH No> with warehouse address (copied from plant address).

Unfortunately, the Custodian was not opened in the SSCUI for editing (different from On premises system). In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the 'Custodian' value will be always the same as the 'Party Entitled to Dispose'. To confirm this behavior, I tested it on my end. When a value is added to the 'Party Entitled to Dispose' field, the 'Custodian' field (in our internal tables) automatically adopts the same value. If the value is removed in the configuration 'Set Warehouse Address', the Custodian field is cleared as well. This linkage ensures no additional action is required on your part.

To configure the Set Warehouse Address in your system, please check the setup guide:

 S4H_588 Warehouse Management Setup.

Best regards,

Geovana

entry.title: Mass deletion of MARD entries for a specific storage location without affecting MARC/MARA
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I’m currently facing the following challenge and would appreciate any advice from the community:

We want to delete a specific storage location (e.g., an external warehouse) from the material master storage location data (MARD) — for all affected materials (~300,000) — without touching any entries in MARC or MARA.

Goal:
Only remove the MARD entries for this storage location – essentially, delete the storage location view from the material master.

Conditions:

  • The same material can exist in multiple storage locations, but only the specified one should be deleted

  • The external storage location is no longer used

  • This should be done per storage location, not per material

My questions:

  1. Has anyone used MM17 for this kind of mass deletion?

  2. Are there any limitations in using MM17 for deleting storage location views in MARD?

  3. Are there alternatives?

  4. Is it supported/safe to delete MARD records directly via standard tools, or is it considered risky?

Any feedback or shared experience would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance and best regards,

K. Xhyra

Greetings,

In the inspection plan I have maintained the following assignemnt to vendor:

I think  your case is not functioaning due to wrong usage of MPN materials. You have described "We have a Material with MPN maintained but being procured from two different vendors but from the same Manufacturer." and if you read the documentation reagrding MPN profiles it is written "Manufacturer will then be applied as a further criterion for dynamization purposes and in the selection of the inspection plan."

I would say that you need to rethink why you are using MPN profiles if the manufacturer is the same and think about a scenario without MPN profile - such scernarios should function but be aware if you are using S4 HANA see note 3467807 !

Best regards, M.

entry.title: Customer Checkout cloud edition - Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post describes how use SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition with SAP Integration Suite.

Prerequisite:

  • Client id and client secret for SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition
  • Access to SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition
  • Access to SAP Integration Suite

Check out this guide how to create client id and client secret
https://community.sap.com/t5/crm-and-cx-blog-posts-by-sap/customer-checkout-cloud-edition-create-technical-user/ba-p/14174481 

Integration Suite Example

1. Start in Integration Suite - Click on Integration and APIs


2. Click on "Security Material"

3. Click on "Create" -> "OAuth 2 Client Credentials"

4. Create new OAuth 2 Client Credentials

 

Field nameExample valueSource of the value
Token Service URLhttps://******.accounts.ondemand.com/oauth2/tokenCCOm, cloud edition
Configuration -> About 
OAuth 2.0 Token endpoint
Client AuthenticationSend as Body Parameter 
Content Typeapplication/x-www-form-urlencoded 
Custom parameterssee below 

Custom parameters

resource urn:sap:identity:application:provider:name:ccom

The last part "ccom" must match with the dependency name specified in SAP Cloud Identity Services

5. Click on "Integrations and APIs". Click on "Create" and create new design

6. Click on "Add" and create a new "Integration Flow". Click on the newly created "Integration Flow"

7. Start Timer

 

8. Configure Timer

9. Request Reply

10. Connect Timer to Ping-Request

11. Create Receiver

12. Connect to Receiver

13. Configure Receiver

14. Create Script

Click on "Processing" and "Select"

Upload the following file as "storeResult.groovy"

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String)
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)
    if (messageLog != null) {
        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString('PingResponse', body, 'text/plain')
    }

    return message;
}

15. Connect Ping-Request to Script and Script to End

16. Click on "Save" and Click on "Deploy"

17. Integration Flow was started

18. Click on "Integrations and APIs" and "All Artifacts"

19. Verify that your test worked well. Click on "Ping-Response" Attachment to verify the result

20. Verify the result

entry.title: Introducing Forms for Cases - SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM
entry.content:
Using forms to capture information about cases and trigger workflows based on form contents. You can also use forms to post information to external systems.

You, as an administrator, can create custom forms and versions for case data entry. If you've enabled forms for a specific case type, you can find the Forms tab on the case detail view. Use conditions to make specific form fields required, read only, or hidden.

Control Palette

Form includes a drag and drop into form designer where you can add text, entry fields, and other controls like check boxes and radio buttons to your form. Each field or control can also include conditions to show or hide the control based on previous data entry. In addition, you can use rules to automatically assign the most appropriate forms to a specific case type.

Text Inputs

  • Text — A single-line text field. This is the default value for an input element.
  • Heading — A single-line text field. This is the display in Level 1 or 2
  • Paragraph — A single-line text field. 
  • Textarea — A multi-line text field.
  • Link — A field for entering a URL. The browser may provide validation to ensure the text is in a valid URL format.

Numeric Inputs

  • Number — A field for entering a number.

Selection Inputs

  • Radio Buttons — A radio button that allows the user to select only one option from a group of choices.
  • Checkbox Group — A checkbox that allows the user to enable or disable.
  • Checkbox — A checkbox that allows the user to enable or disable.
  • Dropdown — A dropdown list that allows the user to select.

 Table Inputs

Each column of the table can be of one of these types (with their corresponding properties):

  • Text
  • Checkbox
  • Number
  • Date
  • Dropdown Menu

 Date and Time Inputs

  • Date — A control for entering a date (year, month, and day).
  • time — A control for entering a time (hour and minute).
  • datetime-local — A control for entering both a date and time, without time zone information.
  • month — A control for entering a month and year.
  • week — A control for entering a week and year.

 Not yet Supported.

  • Password — A single-line text field where the input is obscured to protect sensitive information.
  • Email — A field specifically for entering one or more email addresses. Validation ensures that the text entered is a valid e-mail address.
  • Search — A single-line text field for entering search queries. It may include a control to clear the entered text.
  • Tel — A field for entering a telephone number. Unlike email, it doesn’t enforce a specific syntax, but it may trigger a numeric keypad on mobile devices.

Form Integration

Create an outbound configuration to enable form buttons to send or retrieve data from external systems and to populate values in dropdown menus, radio buttons, and checkbox groups based on a dynamic data source.

Set up an outbound communication system under Settings  > Integration  > Communication Systems.

Pre-requisities

  • SAP Integration Suite or Cloud Integration (CPI) with Custom Iflow Deployed
  • Set up an outbound configuration under form integration for the API call.

Context

Values displayed in dropdown menus, radio buttons, and checkbox groups are populated by making API calls to external systems through SAP Cloud Integration CPI or Integration Suite.

Configure Dynamic Data Source

Set API URLs to populate values in dropdown menus, radio buttons, and checkbox groups based on a dynamic data source.
  1. Go to your profile menu and choose Settings  Forms.
  2. Select a form from the list and select Open Form Builder for the version you want to edit.
  3. Select the form control to use a dynamic data source to populate values.

  1. In the Data Source area, choose Dynamic and then select the globe icon () to open the iFlow Configuration screen.
  2. Select the applicable HTTP data from the outbound configuration that was configured in the Form Integration section.
  3. Select data that you want to send with the API as the iFlow Input. Choose from case, user, or form fields.

    Select Download Request JSON Schema to download the request schema as a file in a JSON format. Upload this file in SAP Cloud Integration while creating message mapping for the API request.

  4. Select Download Response JSON Schema to download the response schema as a file in a JSON format. Upload this file in SAP Cloud Integration when creating message mapping for the API response.
  5. Save the iFlow Configuration.
